course.subject: LABU
course.name: Honors Business Case Analyses
course.description: This course develops students' critical thinking and communication skills as well as awareness of global business issues through a process of comprehending, analyzing and presenting business cases in various disciplines. For students who have this course as a program requirement.

reviews.author: Eamon Suen
reviews.title: LABU as I know it - an amazing experience mashed up with certain chills and horrors
reviews.comment_content: The course mainly revolves around the art of presentation in the business world. As this course is solely taken by GBUS students, it is usually expected for students to be able to understand more than what is written in the powerpoints and course materials. Case studies and theories are the main content of the course, and they cover the psychological aspects of people in business.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor, as I understand, has a very high expectation of the students and would allow a lot of free discussion time. Nora, in particular, is more willing to let us come up with answers than directly giving it to us. It has indeed made it more difficult to complete assignments or get a good grade - but since there are usually a limited number of students in a class (12 in my class) - it definitely is a lot of fun!
reviews.comment_grading:
One thing about LABU is that we don't really know the marks of our final two assignments. I believe it is, possible to ask for the grades in detail, but that itself was quite bothersome.

As for good/bad grades? As a year 1 student who took it in the first semester, I can tell you that the standards are quite high and getting good grades could be quite challenging. Don't expect too much - just enjoy.
reviews.comment_workload:
4 case studies in one semester is borderline suicide. The only thing about LABU is its super intense workload - I am completely fine with everything else.

Basically, you could expect a presentation every week or so; and a big project every three weeks or so. It doesn't sound like a lot - but when you have to read fifteen pages of information every case study and make a 15 minute presentation every time - you would be frustrated.

One good thing is that the work is very diversified; there is one video podcast on a global scenario, one letter on an accounting dilemma, and two presentations with one about ethics in business and the other about cultural factors in business.

All in all, the workload is heavy, but it is definitely possible to learn a lot from it!

reviews.author: Kasina
reviews.comment_content: Good course: It does help develop students' critical thinking and communication skills as well as awareness of global business issues through a process of comprehending, analyzing and presenting business cases in various disciplines.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good teachers: I like Delian and Nora so much! Both of them are very kind and supportive teachers. Their feedback is useful. I like talking to them a lot. They are willing to talk to students after class. Their PPTs are reader-friendly and easy to understand. I like their lessons a lot.

reviews.author: Ginnylcl
reviews.comment_content: There are many case studies and a lot of group work discussion in class. Business cases studied in the course are selected from all different fields which you may find them interesting and fun to learn. Content you have learnt can help with your future presentation skills. Very nice content structure overall.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very lively and not even boring. Many interactions and discussion.
reviews.comment_grading: Rely on how much effort you have put in the course. But in overall, quite a number of students gain pretty good grades.
reviews.comment_workload: To be honest this course shall be more than twice of the workload of LABU2051/LABU2052, but how much you pay your effort, how much you would get :)

reviews.author: nkst
reviews.comment_content: The course mostly consists of presentation skills and case analysis technique. It can eventually be more dull and repetitive. The content can be very general and the cases given are very popular. The theory is somewhat not so important but the practice and exercises of group problem solving and presentation could be very useful and helpful not only in the work force but also for future courses in UST.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is very knowledgeable and interactive in teaching good presentation skills. The teaching style is very flexible which includes some in class discussions and peer-to-peer learning. The class size is relatively small and students can easily interact with each other. The atmosphere is light and easy.
reviews.comment_grading: Unclear and very subjective grading scheme. Most of the time, the grading is split into two parts: 50% weighted on group performance and 50% on individual performance.
reviews.comment_workload: A heavy course with two classes per week and four projects (three cases and one global business focus project) per semester. Most of the projects are done in groups. With compulsory attendance, students are not expected to miss classes.

reviews.author: finalyearjj
reviews.comment_content: Simple presentation stuff ranging from powerpoint layout to posture and pronunciation. Basically the goal of the course is to make you become a native english speaker and an excellent presenter.
reviews.comment_teaching: Delian is a very helpful and caring instructor. During the student movement period, she didn't take attendance.
reviews.comment_grading: For some reasons, my class have very weird grades. Therefore, no comment.
reviews.comment_workload: Nothing special. Prepare powerpoint slides that are both colourful and professional, and try your best to reduce words on it and you are good to go. Also, be active in class.
